The men break up and go about their business, they move i all directions, but Keltner starts for the doorway to the barracks and is detoured by the guard who knew he would, he stands in the way of Keltner who has to turn away and about his business... the Guard peeks into the barracks.
Helmut still sleeping...
He is delighted... he grabs the door and slams it shut wi a bang that would wake the dead... then opens it again an walks off...

He jumps from out of his hard sleep... foggy and unsure a where he is, what time it is and he looks around and sees the barracks are empty... and he panics... but he is also shivering... the barracks feel like the inside of a meat  truck refrigerated somewhat below zero... Helmut grabs his pants from the front of his bunk, pulls cover over him and tries to get the pants on under the  cover... It is cold!  (Photographically, we can show "col Props:  vapor/smoke.) He gets his pants on and jumps down onto the cold floor a dances from the ice-like floor, he bends down looking for his socks and shoes... he wears just a tee-shirt... Having trouble finding both shoes, he grabs the blanket a and covers himself with it, while searching for the other shoe... He finds the other shoe and proceeds to put them on... ta a beat and sees he has no socks on... reaches under the b and pulls out the pair of socks... which stand straight u (from the cold ... he holds them in the air, and drops on at a time and they sound like "pans" hitting the floor... takes one and blows warm air from his mouth into the sock one at a time, which warms them... (Props:  the socks nee discussion!) He then proceeds to put his shoes on and puts one on, and then the other... now wearing both shoes he starts to tie the laces... he pulls them straight away to tie and they  stand straight up!  (Props:  this is done with leather la pure leather... it works without any unnecessary rigging!

He finally gets them tied and starts, still sleepily, int the toilet area... (We can go for a great sound joke here He steps into the latrine, closes the door and we HEAR th SOUND of crushed ice being poured into the bowl... he flu and we HEAR what might sound like an ice crusher... he st out of the latrine and walks over to the basin and turns water on.
The water spigots... they both read "COLD".

And as he takes some water on his hands to his face... it "cold" and his face just freezes from the pain of the col he looks around and sees the little metal ashtray, that l like a small bowl or a tin from a used shaving cream lath soap... he fills it with water.. and to show his ingenuit he takes a lighter from his pocket, places the tin on the edge of the sink and lights the fire under the tin (which couldn't possibly hold more than a handful of water) and  proceeds to heat same... Once he is satisfied that it is at least warmer than the  spigot supplied, he grabs for the tin which is so hot fro the burning, he screams in another type pain... the pain "HOT" hurting... he decides to flick his fingers in the t bowl and splash some of the water on his face (which is b now, just drips of water)... brushes his teeth with his f and soap... straightens his hair and exits the toilet to bunk to get his shirt... another "ICE COLD" item... he fe how cold it is, and doesn't have the courage for another  climate blast... he rolls up his shirt and places it unde his armpit to warm it... as it hits under his arm... the  cold just about wipes him out... he decides to sit on it. and he does.
He's been peeking all the while... He figures he's had hi laugh, and it's the first time we see he can laugh... he  steps into the barracks area, and yells:
Doork!  Move it out, and on the  double!! Helmut jumps with fright, unravels his shirt, runs toward the open door putting on his shirt as we

Most of the men are clustered around their bunks, and in dull light we see some of them in the aisles, talking, pl cards... while most of the others are whistling, clapping and laughing as Uhlmann does his silly little clog dance. it is apparent the ugly episode between Galt and Uhlmann been forgotten for the moment. The lights are hung from cords down off the ceiling and f a complex this size it could use ten... there are but two Uhlmann is having the time of his ignorant life... the mo the men applaud, the more he "clog dances".
They are both seated on their top bunk, Adolf enjoying th poor dance Uhlmann is giving as Ludwig looks down the ais towards Helmut's bunk.
(nudging Adolf)

It looks like Helmut found some new  ears to listen to his Super Star  fantasies... Adolf takes a look, shrugs his shoulder, as if to say I  couldn't care less... and goes on watching the action of  Uhlmann and the other men...
(to himself, but for  Adolf to hear as  well; a la  Shakespeare, mimicking  Helmut)
Ringling Brothers would have done  anything for me to appear with them  but I had to do what was best for  me!

head_text.subj: HELMUT AND THE FOUR NEW PRISONERS

text: The four new men are surrounding Helmut on the top of his bunk listening to his bragging.
So I told Mr. Ringling if he wanted  "Helmut" he'd have to bring his circus  to Germany... I am a German, I told  him, and my responsibility is to my  own people who are my biggest fans.
Did you really say that?
(proudly)
Of course I did... they offered me  anything...  anything I wanted to go  with them.

Hey! I saw the circus in Berlin about  four years ago...  Didn't  you make  your entrance in a long tail coat  with a pair of tails on the jacket  about fifty feet long?  Sure!  And a  funny Little clown at the very end  carrying the tails like a woman's  train? Helmut studies the prisoners glare and decides he couldn' even remember the clown he saw was Gustav the Great, why  not?  No one would ever know... and he nods with a kind o studied humility... yes.
You were great! Helmut eats it up.

You should have seen him... You'd  never know it was him... with the  long tails  and white tie... red  nose...  long hair...  and a battered  top hat... with the hair hanging way  down to his shoulders...  and, ah,  let me see... oh, yeah... your mouth  went from ear to ear.
(softly)
Right!
How do "clowns" ever come up with  such ideas for faces and make-up?
It doesn't happen overnight... it  takes years and years... You try  many faces, then finally you hit the  one that's just right for you.

My kids will never believe this, I  can't wait to... tell... His voice trails off as he realizes the hopelessness of w he was about to say.  This puts a damper on the discussio and the men start to break up and get down off the bunk. Helmut, seeing his captive audience leaving... panics.
(emotionally)
Wait, let me tell you some other  things...  I mean things that are  really exciting and...  please!   Please... let me just have a few  more...
(ignoring Helmut  completely)

What's going on with those guys? He's looking off down the aisle where Uhlmann has his  audience... The four prisoners move out into the aisle to get a better look, leaving Helmut perched on his bunk wit pleading and broken look of despair...
(a last attempt)
Did you know "clowns" literally  bequeath their faces to their sons,  or sometimes to... He realizes it's futile as the four new prisoners move to Uhlmann and the others down the aisle...

Come on, let's see what's such fun... He moves and the others move along with him.  Helmut thin about joining them, and starts to move off his bunk but h body won't respond... he just hangs there limply... his h lowered, a sad man.
SHOOTING OVER the men placing Helmut in the very deep  b. as we see the four new prisoners walk over to watch the  action...

Uhlmann is just finishing his dance with a spin, when he  finally gets dizzy and topples over on one of the bunks. All the men applaud wildly.  Uhlmann laying half down and half up on the lower bunk he landed on, breathing heavily yells over to Galt...

Hey, Galt, it's your turn, how about  doin' one of your belly dances for  us? All the men agree and start yelling for Galt to do it...  Galt moves out into the center of the aisle in the cleari made by the men, and holds up his hands for silence... th quiet down and Galt looks around until he spots Keltner.
Reverend? The men become very still, they look from Galt to Keltner and back to Galt, their eyes reflecting suspicion of him, wondering what he's up to now.  Galt is fully aware of th
Well, Reverend, what do you think?   Would a little belly-dancing be too  much for the boys? Keltner studies Galt for a beat, then accepts his offer o truce.
(moving over towards  Galt)

A little fun is what we need... so...   if you'll all hold the noise down,  I'll join in. A hushed cheer goes up from the men as Keltner stands bes Galt.  Galt holds his hands over his head and nods for Ke to do the same thing.  The Reverend does, and now Galt be undulating his hips.  Keltner studies the move for a beat and then does the same thing but with comical awkwardness Franz starts playing a slow sensuous rhythm on his harmon The men clap and whistle softly.

He is sitting upright on top of his bunk, watching what G has Keltner doing, a look of disgust passes his face as h turns away from what he'd been watching and gets busy wit his papers and figuring again.

They are just finishing their dance.  The men applaud wil but softly... Keltner, puffing, moves over to the side an sits on one of the bunks to catch his breath.  Galt takes few bows, and the men react with applause and whistling t beginning to take on "noise" proportions... Keltner motio for the men to hold it down... and they do.
Say, why don't we get the clown to  do something?
A clown?  Who's a clown??
You've heard of "Helmut Doork".   That's him down there!
Don't waste your time.  You'll never  get the Great Doork to do anything.
as he starts walking towards Helmut's bunk...

Oh, I'm sure he will! The others follow right behind.  There is a look on Keltn face like he would like to stop them, but between his puf and his certainty that Helmut will be alright, he stays w he is.
as he walks with the others.
You're wasting your time.  He doesn't  perform for the likes of us... he'll  turn you down.
He's right, we've been asking him  for three years...  I have a feeling  he only does his little routines for  the crowned heads of Europe.
And, of course, the BIG heads of  Berlin. There is general laughter... as the group arrives at Helm bunk.

He sees something's going to happen, he puts his papers a and sits upright... waiting... his eyes catch Galt's eyes peering at him. Galt tells it all with his eyes... This one isn't "sacred to the men... he might just be the pigeon Galt's been hop for... the one every bully looks for, for his own brand o fun.
How about it, Doork?
(swinging his legs  around ready to jump  down)
I'd like to, but I can't... really...  I can't.
(strongly)
Can't?  Did I hear you say you can't?
(it stops him in his  tracks; he stays up  on the bunk)
I'd like to do something... but... (pointing to the 2nd  New Prisoner)
He can tell you... He's seen me  work...  I need props... make-up...   I work with a lot of different  things...
That's right... I did... and he does!
(in fast)
Sure, tell them... I can't just do  anything...  I need lights, props,  my costume. Galt doesn't like no for an answer...
(gritting his teeth)

Now, me and these... gentlemen...   we don't expect you to do your "act",  just a little something that'll give  us a laugh, that's all. Keltner moves in from o.s. and stands at the back of the  group watching and listening.
(to all the men)
Aw, forget it... and that's probably  his problem...  he's forgotten how!
(trying to suck him  in)
Wait a minute, you guys... show people  have to be in a mood... (to Franz)
Play a little music, like in a  circus... Franz starts playing his harmonica... slowly...
There!  Ain't that nice?  Don't it  put you in a mood?
(getting fed up)
I TOLD YOU!  I need things to do my  act.

Hey, Doork, what about that drunk  routine... that was funny... Helmut looks at him puzzled... he can't think or remember anything at this point... certainly not anything relating any of the previous lies he's told...
(pacifying his head  off)
Yeah, that drunk thing...  that does  sound funny...
I still need many things... props  and...
(puzzled)
I don't remember you using anything  in that drunk routine.
(starting to fume)
Hey... are you trying to fool us? With this Keltner moves in and up to Galt.
Leave him alone!
Stay out of this, Reverend. We're  not doing anything... We just want  him to join in the fun.
(to the men)
Right!  If a Reverend can give us a  laugh, why not a clown? All the men ad lib their agreement with what Uhlmann just said; it appears that they are all on Galt's side, and Ke knows it.
(to Helmut, softly)
It doesn't have to be anything  special... a little dance, maybe?
(taking it all out on  Keltner)
Like that disgusting exhibition you  did?  Oh, no... not me!
Go on, Doork, so I can tell my kids.
Can't you get it through your heads,  I need...
(firmly)
WE need you to give us a laugh. Galt grabs Helmut's jacket and pulls him off the bunk, no to nose to him...

So... TRY! Galt has Helmut by the neck portion of the jacket, practi choking him to death... his vice-like hands are closing i on his throat and Helmut's trying vainly just to breathe. One of the prisoners starts pounding his feet and making march-like noise yelling from the other end... "So try!". "So try!"... "So try!"... "So try!"... the other prisoner in the barracks pick up the chant and the stomping... Kel doesn't even hear the racket they've started because of h concern for Helmut being choked to death... He tries to l Galt's hands from Helmut's throat.
That's enough, leave him alone!

Stay out of it, Reverend! Galt spins Helmut around so that his back is facing the a and he walks him into the center area... the other men fe this violence happening, and watching.  Helmut being chok triggers all of their venom and their hate and they reall come on strong... stomping, yelling...
(ad lib)

Choke him harder...  see if that's  funny!  Make him dance! Hey, Doork!...   be funny now! He don't look so funny  to me!  He sure as hell looks funny  to me!  Hey, Galt, pull his string  and make the dummy funny! And they stomp and they stomp and they stomp... "So try!" "So try!"... They get louder and louder... Helmut is kick his legs, which are off the ground, and Galt won't let go

His face is turning color... he hasn't a lot of air left his lungs... and Keltner is practically hanging onto Galt trying to get his hands loose... and Galt could carry ano three men without batting an eye.  Galt puts him down slo in the middle of the aisle, so that just his feet touch t ground, but he keeps his hands around his throat.
Your public is calling, clown...  now, clown!
SHOOTING OVER Galt, Keltner and Helmut, we see the door o the barracks slam open and bang against the wall making m noise than anything all the men made together, and they a freeze...

He stands in the doorway, legs spread apart, hands on his waist... and he is wearing a raincoat, the barracks has b totally silent... all that is heard is the rain pecking a on the roof.  Galt has let go of Helmut who just lays on floor with Galt and Keltner on both sides of him...
(walking slowly into  the barracks)
What is going on here? (to Helmut)
On your feet! Helmut gets up, dizzily, just about getting oxygen back i his system...
(like a little boy)
He was showing us some of his funny  clown falls... The Guard surveys the faces of the others as they stare b
Because of all the noise coming from  in here -- I have been called up  front to explain...  I don't like to  be called up front...  I don't like  to have to explain... (menacingly)
And, you might not like it, either. (a beat)
Back to your bunks, all of you...   Turn out the lights, and keep it

As the guard turns to the door to go, Helmut takes a step forward about to stop the guard, Keltner grabs his arm an turns him the other way... the Guard exits closing the do quietly behind him... The men start to disperse... Galt g Helmut a "I'll get you for this" look and returns to his bunk with Uhlmann almost up his ass following... Keltner  leads Helmut back to their bunk.
(whispering)
I was just going to ask him about  the forms... my release...
(shaking his head)
That was not the time, believe me! Keltner sits Helmut down next to him on his lower bunk, a Helmut rubs his throat, and tries swallowing a few times.
Hurt much?
(beaten)
No, I'm alright... thank you. They both sit in silence... Helmut breaks the silence...
Johann, why do they pick on me?   I've never done anything to them.
You've never done anything for them! Helmut dislikes Keltner's remark and gets up from the low bunk and starts up to his.  He gets to the top bunk and s to get onto it, stops and whispers to Keltner.
You think I should have performed?

The men would have appreciated it. Helmut rolls into his bunk, the lights go out and he lies his back staring at the ceiling.  Keltner sits on the sid of his bunk and takes his shoes off... periodically the r from the searchlights revolving outside cross the windows momentarily flood the barracks with light.  After a few  seconds, Helmut leans over to whisper to Keltner.
Johann!
(he stands up, eye  level with Helmut)
What is it?
They don't believe me, do they?  I  mean about being a clown?
Oh, I'd say you've convinced most.   However -- (a long beat)
There is one you haven't convinced... Helmut stares at Keltner, knowing full well what's coming yet doesn't have the courage to take the chance that it m be another thought... so he waits...
(gently)
You, Helmut... you!

The truth of Keltner's charge hits Helmut with an overpow force.  He looks at Keltner for a beat... his eyes filled with pain, then slowly turns away from him, leaving him  standing there as we PAN with Helmut and HOLD on...
The rain is pouring down.
It is the next morning, a chilly, damp day following a ni of rain.

Attention!  Attention!  All prisoners  will assemble immediately in the  yard.  All prisoners will assemble  immediately in the yard. Attention!   Attention! The loudspeakers repeat the command.  Across the muddy, p splotched yard, a barbed wire barricade about six feet hi has been erected, dividing the camp in two.  A number of  guards patrol the fence on both sides.
Uhlmann is looking out into the yard.  He motions to some to "take a look at this".
Galt has just arrived at the window where Uhlmann is stan
They've put up barbed wire!
They look at each other in wonder as they start into the  aisle.  The men in the barracks are frantically trying to organize themselves.

The prisoners are pouring out of the barracks doorway.  G and Uhlmann are already standing outside as Helmut, Keltn Herman, Adolf, Franz, Ludwig, Stout Prisoner, New Prisone join them.  All look o.s. momentarily speechless at what  they see.
What the hell... ?
Beyond the fence we see men, women and children standing groups near the barracks on that side of the camp.  The S of children crying can be heard.
As they quickly scurry to line up in front of their own h
Youngsters!  They've got youngsters  over there.
Women!
Another fence!
Helmut stands next to him.
What does it mean?  What do they  need a fence for?
(shaking his head)
Misery loves company.  Looks like  they're going to deny us even that. The Guard is shoving the late-comers into place.
All right.  All right, move.  Hurry  it up.  Move.

SHOOTING ACROSS the prisoners in f.g. toward the new fenc Guards move among the men, herding them into lines.  On t other side of the fence, we can see the new arrivals lini up, being prodded into place by Guards.

On both sides of the fence, the prison inmates have assem in the wet, forbidden yard.  On one side are the regular  prisoners, who watch the guards warily as they straighten their lines.  On the other side are the new prisoners --  about two hundred frightened Jews of all ages, including  thirty or forty children and a number of very old men and women.  They stand in absolute silence as the loudspeaker blare again, except for the crying children.

Attention!  The Commandant issues  the following special order:  the  north side of the camp is now  temporary quarters for non-Aryan  prisoners.  Fraternizing between  Aryan and non-Aryan prisoners is  strictly prohibited.  Any violation  of this order will be severely  punished.  Heil Hitler... Repeating...
SHOOTING THROUGH the booted, outspread legs of a soldier  guard in f.g. toward the line of prisoners behind him.  O woman holds a child of about three who cries inconsolably

The Commandant issues the following  special order: As the announcement is read, the guard's legs turn around and he walks away from the CAMERA toward the woman.  He s before her menacingly, and she clutches the child closer her in a futile attempt to hush its crying.
The north side of the camp is now  temporary quarters for non-Aryan  prisoners.  Fraternizing between  Aryan and non-Aryan prisoners is...

SHOOTING along line of prisoners from barracks H to show  their various reactions as the announcement continues --  disdain, surprise, sympathy and relief.  The guard stands with his back to the line at the end farthest from the CA Galt is near the CAMERA.
(under his breath)
Jews! Prisoners nearest to Galt eye him questioningly.

... strictly prohibited.  Any  violation of this order will be  severely punished.  Heil Hitler. The loudspeakers go dead.  The prisoners stand silently  studying the new arrivals across the yard.  The new priso self-consciously file back into their huts on the other s of the fence.  As the prisoners begin to break rank --

Prisoners from barracks H remain in  line.  Barracks H will remain in  line. The prisoners turn and look in direction of the Guard as  they straighten their lines.  The guard paces slowly alon the line inspecting it silently.  On the fringes of the s we can see prisoners from other barracks gathering to see what their fellow convicts are in for.
Finally he stops and contemplates his shabby charges with disgust.

I said last night I didn't think I  would enjoy being called up to account  for the noise coming from barracks  H.  I can tell you this morning I  didn't enjoy it. He walks down the line, looking at each man.
I don't know what caused the trouble  last night, but I'm not blaming you  entirely. (fatherly)
I failed you.  I should have seen  that you all have much too much energy  for the confined life you lead here. (he smiles benevolently)
We're going to correct that.  I've  been told that energy comes from  food.
Their faces reflect that they know what is coming.
SHOOTING PAST the line of prisoners in f.g. to the Guard, who has paused to let his words sink in.
So... to help you... all rations are  canceled for the next... forty-eight  hours. A hushed ripple of ad lib grumbling and growling rolls al the line of prisoners.
And, if that doesn't quiet you down,  I'll think of some other ideas you'll  like even less. I'm going to make  this barracks the quietest in the  camp. (roaring)
Is that clear? The prisoners are silent but their faces register their  resentment.
Now, don't blame me. (with sly meaning)
I didn't start the trouble last night. The truth of what he has said is reflected in the faces o the men.
Fall out.
As they stand with the other prisoners, watching the guar move off.  Keltner looks worried, the others are angry, H seems undecided as his eyes follow the guard.
Bastard!

I can't go without food. I'll starve. Suddenly Helmut makes up his mind and starts off after th Guard.  Keltner, sensing the mood of the men, puts a  restraining hand on his arm, whispers to him hoarsely.

Helmut, don't. But Helmut shakes him off and hurries away. The other prisoners notice where he is headed and exchang looks.  Keltner shakes his head.  Galt's eyes narrow as h watches Helmut run off after the guard.
(loudly)
He's the one we can thank for the  diet.
The CAMERA MOVES BACKWARD as the Guard strides toward it, his face sour.  Behind him we can see Helmut running to c up to him.  When he is close enough...
Sir?  Corporal... The guard stops and turns so abruptly that Helmut almost  runs into him.
What?
(obsequiously)
Doork.  Helmut Doork.  Remember?   The papers... You said... Remember  the special forms for the Gestapo to  review my case.

No papers. He stalks off.  Helmut starts to say something more but t better of it.  Crushed, he starts back towards his barrac head down.  He walks sadly for several steps, then looks and stops, his expression changing to one of uneasiness.

A dozen of Helmut's barracks-mates, including Galt, Uhlma Adolf, Ludwig, Herman, the Stout Prisoner, several of the New Prisoners, are drifting across the yard towards him, the looks on many faces bode no good for Helmut.

The men converge and form a half circle around him. As the men close in on him, he moves back until we cna se the barbed wire fence behind him.  Helmut senses their  disposition and remains warily silent.  Keltner and Franz stand slightly behind the pack.
What'd you say now, Mr. Doork,  Almighty! (to men)
Last night he wouldn't give us a  laugh.  Today they won't give us  food.
(venomously)
What were you doing?  Making a deal  with your guard pal to slip you some  food?
(indignantly)
No!  I was asking him about the forms  he'd promised to get me. (admonishing)
Because of last night... I'm not  getting them. Keltner, seeing how disappointed Helmut is, moves up thro the group.
(encouragingly)
When this blows over, Helmut, we'll...
(interrupting)
Don't feel sorry for him.  He's got  no one to blame but himself.  The  whole thing was his doing.
He's been telling us how great he  is; how funny.  Why?  Why couldn't  he have done a trick or two for us?
The Reverend did a turn.  What's so  special about him? The men voice agreement... Helmut should have performed. Helmut starts to go around one end of the semi-circle but the men bar his way.

Don't start anything here.  We're in  enough trouble. The other prisoners in the b.g., those who have remained the yard to see what was going to happen to the men of  barracks H, sense trouble, the kind they want no part of, and begin scurrying back to their own barracks.
We're not starting anything, we're  finishing something.
We've decided Doork here is going to  keep us laughing so hard we won't be  able to hear our stomachs growling.
Better hurry it up, clown.  'Cause  my stomach's growling already. Can  you hear it?
Hear it!  The whole place hears it. The men take a few steps toward Helmut as they call for h to perform.

Yeah, Doork, do a trick. How about  that night in Munich when they  wouldn't stop laughing.  How about  it, Doork? Come on, just a little  trick.  Give us one laugh.  That's  all we're asking for.  Come on,  Helmut, do something. Helmut, hoping to stall the inevitable, still hoping to  preserve for a while longer his beautiful myth of being a great clown, holds up his hands for the men to be quiet. Franz interpreting the gesture as giving in to the demand of the men...
(excitedly)
He's going to do it!  He's going to  do it! The men quiet down and move back a few steps to give Helm room.
(grandly)

Nothing pleases an artist more than  to perform.  I'm going to do a real  show for you.  All I ask is that you  give me a little time...  time to  get things together...  things I can  use as props...  I'll even try to  make a costume, and...
You don't need a costume.  We've got  imagination.
Right? Murmurs of agreement.
Do the drunk pretzel like the kid  suggested last night.
(commanding)
And do it now, clown.  No more  stalling. Helmut, still trying to hold on to his dream of greatness draws himself up proudly and begins to move forward.
Let me through.
Aren't we good enough for you?
He'd do his tricks fast enough if  his guard pal asked him.  Wouldn't  you, Doork? As the mention of the word "guard" the mood of the men tu ugly.
Their faces show their determination that Helmut will per or... else.
Do something, Karl.  For God's sake,  do something.
And be sure it's funny.
Helmut is frightened.  He strains to look beyond the men help.  He opens his mouth to scream for the Guard, but Ga puts his hand over Helmut's mouth.
(his face pressed  close to Helmut's)
You make us scream... scream with  laughter...  or I'll tear you to  shreds on the wire. Galt presses Helmut right up to the barbed wire fence so can feel the barbs in his back.
Galt takes his hand away from Helmut's mouth.  Helmut doe utter a sound.  He knows that Galt and the men mean busin and he now must do something.  He nods his head.

All right... all right. The men move back to give him room.  Frantically, he trie to think of something to do... he knows it must be great. or else his myth will explode.  He walks around in a litt circle, trying, trying to think of something.  Finally he faces them.  He bows his legs and pretends he's a bow-leg man trying to walk a high wire, but he's so frightened th result is pathetic, not funny.
The camera works across their faces, which are expression

They play with fierce rigor f such emaciated men, yelling at each other and kicking up  clouds of dust as they try to work off their frustrations On the non-Aryan side of the fence, the children, now abo 50 in number, are grouped near the wire barricades starin across it, their faces dour.
