Shooting past the soccer players in f.g. toward the fence Through the men we can see the children, but the play mov away from them.  They continue to stare straight ahead,  obviously watching something else.  Suddenly many of them press close to the fence straining to see.
Helmut can be seen standing in the doorway.  After a beat he quickly retreats back into the barrack.

The CAMERA MOVES BACKWARD down the aisle between the bunk as Helmut walks dejectedly down the aisle, nervously fing his white ascot.  The barrack is empty except for Keltner who is arranging the sprouts of his potato plant over a l trellis of sticks.  Helmut turns and walks back up the ai to stand in front of Keltner.
I can't go out there.  I can't take  another day of them staring at me.
They'll get over it.  Disappointment  is no stranger to those children.
They look at me as though it was all  my fault.  Haven't they been told  why I can't...
I'm sure they have.
Then why do they stare?
(holding up the plant)

It's amazing how a thing like this  can feed off itself.  Think how lucky  we would be if we could do that. Helmut glances disinterestedly at the plant as he reaches to his bunk and brings down the coat belonging to Franz. holds coat up for Keltner to see.
I sewed a button on.  Look all right?
(inspecting coat)
Fine. Helmut gently pats the coat, then folds it and puts it ba on his bunk.
I did make them laugh.  Didn't I? Keltner nods.
(angrily)
I wish they'd get them out of here.   Prison is no place for little  children.
We've been all over that before.   You've got to stop thinking about  them.
(trying to convince  himself)
You're right!  I've got to think of  myself. Keltner puts the plant under his bunk and gets up.
It's too hot in here.  I'm going to  get some air.
Johann... do you think there's any  possible way I could talk to the  Commandant.  Maybe I could make him  understand... The sentence trails off as Helmut realizes how useless hi suggestion is.
There's nothing you can do... but  forget.
How can I!  They were my own very  special audience.  And now they stare  at me as if I had betrayed them.
They're children, Helmut.  You can't  expect them to understand the madness  of adults.
(sudden thought)
If I could talk to them.  To the  children themselves -- that would  help, wouldn't it? Keltner doesn't answer but he watches Helmut with new  interest.
If I explain it to them -- then  they'll know I am not mad at them.
(very deliberately)
You go near that fence once again...  and you're taking your life in your  own hands.  You know that as well as  I do.
(pleading)
I would just need a minute.  A minute  to talk to them. Helmut goes to the door and looks out.
The children are still pressed against the fence, still t to get a glimpse of Helmut
Helmut stands just inside the doorway... looking out.
I wish to God I didn't care.  I wish  to God I could forget them. Helmut walks back to Keltner.
But I can't. Helmut looks at Keltner, his eyes pleading for help.
I'm going to ask you a question,  Helmut, and I want you to think  carefully before you answer. Helmut nods.
The reason you can't get them out of  your mind -- is it because you need  them -- for you audience? Helmut drops his eyes as he attempts to find the right an
I want the truth.
(after a moment)
I know I can't perform for them  anymore.  I know that. (a beat)

I really don't know what the reason  is.  I think it's got something to  do with... well, I don't want those  little ones to think I've turned  against them, too.  That's why I've  got to do something.  Something. Keltner studies Helmut for a moment.
You'll be taking a chance.  A great  chance. Helmut nods that he know this.
(very definite)
All right!  Come on then.
Where are you going?
You want to talk to the children?   Well, I think I can help you.
There's no reason for you to get  involved in this.

Reason?  When war is waged against  children!  That is reason enough for  the whole damn world to get involved.   And it will, believe me, it will. Keltner puts his arm around Helmut's shoulder.  Helmut gr a broad grin of thanks.
So, come on, Doork the Great, let's  start getting involved. They both walk quickly to the door.
As Keltner and Helmut come out.  In the b.g. we can see t soccer game still going on, the players shouting excitedl at each other.  Keltner surveys the scene for a moment.
Wait here. He moves down the line of barracks toward the mess hall.

As Keltner moves among the men lounging around the barrac talking and watching the soccer game.  Trying to appear a nonchalant as possible, we whispers something to a group prisoners.  They glance back at Helmut and then nod.  Kel moves on to another group, taking care to avoid the two y guards, one of which is the guard in charge of Barrack "H Again Keltner murmurs something to the other prisoners, a again they look at Helmut and nod assent.  Keltner goes o to another group.  As he does, the men in the first group casually disperse and start across the yard toward the fe moving around the soccer players.  One of them goes up to Ludwig, who is playing in the match, and whispers somethi to him.  Ludwig nods, and the other prisoners move away. Ludwig runs off chasing the "ball".
as he storms into a clutch of players, including Galt, al kicking at the "ball".
(low to Galt)
Kessler is going to talk to the  children. Cover him.
(mean)
Who says so?
(evenly)
The Reverend says cover him... so we  cover him. The players around Galt give him a meaningful look and he gets their message.
All right!  I was just asking.

As Keltner's plot takes shape, we see a dozen or so priso wander, apparently aimlessly, across the yard and form a  spectator's section for the soccer game with their backs the fence, thus providing a shield between the children a the guards.  The game picks up tempo, but the play someho stays in the center of the yard, strengthening the shield
As he watches the plan in action.  Keltner rejoins him.
You know what to do? Helmut nods.
Stay behind the men and keep an eye  out for the guards on the other side.
Right.
Make it quick.  You won't have much  time. Helmut nods again and starts away, but Keltner stops him

And Helmut, keep the children quiet.   We don't want trouble. Helmut nods and moves off across the yard.  The CAMERA FO him as he circles around the soccer players, trying to lo as if he is just wandering over to join the other spectat As he nears the other side, the children spot him and rea pressing closer to the fence and pointing to him.

Shooting past the children in f.g. toward Helmut as he ne the line of prisoners, who continue to ad lib shouts of  derision and encouragement to the soccer players.  The  children begin ad libbing cries of greeting to Helmut.  H puts his fingers to his lips to silence them and takes hi place in the line with his back to them.
as he stands pretending to watch the soccer game with the others.
(shouting)
Kick it, Ludwig.  Kick it! The prisoner next to him gives him a sidelong glance and  nods almost imperceptibly.  Quickly, Helmut ducks behind line.
Behind the line as he scurries, bending over, to the fenc The children flock to him.  The CAMERA FOLLOWS him to the fence.
Doork, Doork, Doork is back.  It's  Doork.  It's Doork. Helmut tries to silence their squeals of delight.  Holdin finger to his lips:
Shhh.  Shhhh.  The guards... The children quiet down and press closer to the fence.  H drops to his knees, looking around.
Do a trick, Doork.  Please, Doork,  please, please.
No, no.  I can't.  The guards won't  let me.  Not now.  Maybe some other  day.
This is the same flaxen-haired little five-year-old with doll we saw before.  She regards Helmut solemnly.
They're bad.

Smiling wryly at the simplicity of this appraisal, Helmut reaches through the fence and pats the head of the girl's doll. Eager to touch Helmut, another child take his hand, other grab at his arm.  Still other youngsters, following this  lead, try to reach through the fence to touch him.  Obvio enjoying this adulation, Helmut takes as many of the litt hands as he can, squeezing them affectionately.  Only one group of eight children hangs back.  They do not seem to  understand what this is all about.  Their little faces ar fearful, yet they are fascinated by Helmut.  Suddenly one little boy gives a yelp of pain and backs away from the w clutching his forearm.
What is it?  What happened?

He hurt himself. Wide-eyed with fright, the little boy takes his hand away from his arm to reveal a nasty looking scratch from one o the barbs on the fence.  Seeing his own injury, the young bursts into tears.
Shhh.  Shhh.  Don't cry.  It's going  to be all right. (to the other children)

Be careful when you're near this  fence. He consoles the little boy, who continues to cry and hold up his wounded arm for Helmut to see.  Helmut looks aroun frantically, as if hoping to find help somewhere.  Then h quickly removes his ascot -- his precious trademark, the  symbol of his self-accorded status -- and hands it throug the fence.

Here, wrap this around it.  I'll  make it all better. The little boy goes on crying, but some of the other chil take the cravat and fashion it into a crude bandage aroun the youngster's arm.  It fails to silence the boy's cryin however.
(worried)

Hush now.  Stop crying.  Please.   Look... Look at this. He begins shuffling around on his knees, imitating a duck an effort to appease the crying child.  As he goes, Helmu quacks softly.  The boy stops crying, but his face remain unhappy.  The other children laugh in spite of Helmut's  efforts to keep them quiet, all but the group of eight  youngsters who only stare at Helmut in awe.  Seeing that is making progress with the crying child, Helmut next pul his coat up over his head and, still on his knees, moves  around like a headless man, groping ahead with his hands.
His frown gradually dissolves and, in spite of his sniffl he smiles, timorously at first, then broadly.  Finally, h laughs.
Helmut shrugs his jacket back into place and smiles at th boy.

There, that's better.  No more crying  now. For the first time he notices the other group of frowning children.  Among the other smiling and laughing youngster they seem to stand out.  When Helmut fastens a quizzical  look on them, they back away a little, fearfully.
What's the matter with them?
They're new.  We can't understand  them.  All they do is cry.
They're all the way from  Czechoslovakia. The eight just start at him wordlessly, their fear naked their eyes.
(to the silent ones)
There's nothing to be afraid of.   Everything is all right. When there is no reaction from the children, who obviousl don't understand him, Helmut looks over his shoulder,  wondering if he has time.
The prisoners are still rooting for the soccer players, b as Helmut looks, Adolf, in the middle of the cheering sec turns and sees him.
(a hushed call)
Hurry up.
Helmut nods to Adolf and then turns back to the youngster afraid but still unable to tear himself away.

Here.  Look.  I'll show you... No  noise now. In pantomime, he pretends to pull a hair from his head an threads it through an imaginary needle.  Finally accompli this, he pretends to be sewing a button on his jacket, ho the thumb of his left hand under the button while he sews with his right.  When he has finished, he pantomimes that has sews his thumb to the jacket.  He pretends to be  embarrassed and tries to hide his hand in his trouser poc but in order to put his hand in his pocket the jacket goe too.  The children giggle, then roar with laughter at his frantic efforts to detach his thumb from his jacket. The silent children press closer to watch Helmut's antics Some look at each other and smile, then grin.  Suddenly t entire group is laughing.  Helmut holds up his hands for  silence, but the grin on his face says he loves it.
No, no, be quiet.  Be quiet.  Shhh.   Shhhh. The children go on laughing as if this is just part of th game.

The SOUND of the children's laughter floats up to two gua in a tower on the non-Aryan side of camp.  One of them, w has been watching the soccer game below, nudges his partn and points down to Helmut.
Between the children at the fence and the line of soccer  spectators we can see only the top of Helmut's head bobbi up and down.  But that is enough.
After a long look, one of the guards picks up a telephone and starts to make a call.

Helmut seems to have thrown caution away under the stimul of the children's laughter.  He is on his feet trying a h spring.  He lands flat on his back, but rolls over on his side and grins broadly at his audience, which laughs  appreciatively.  This is the old Doork.  Their Doork.  Ag Helmut tries the hand spring and again he flops.

A HIGH ANGLE with Helmut and the children in f.g. and bey them the Aryan side of the yard.  The soccer game is stil in progress, with the spectators on both sides of the act whooping it up.  Then in b.g. we see two soldiers, two SS officers, and the guard in charge of barracks "H", come  bursting through the spectators near the huts and into th game itself.  The players slowly subside as they realize  what is happening.  They watch the guard cross the yard. The cheering trails off, and the yard becomes strangely q the prisoners' warning to Helmut.

Oblivious to all this in his joy at performing for the  children again, Helmut is just pretending to slip on some underfoot.  His arms flay the air as he tries to regain h balance, but he falls.  Through this, however, the childr seem to be watching something behind Helmut, and when he  lands on the ground, they do not laugh. Again their faces are frightened as they look o.s.  Helmu looks at them, puzzled.  Then, realizing that something i wrong, he turns and looks up from the ground.

SHOOTING PAST Helmut in f.g. toward the guard, SS men, an soldiers, who have come through the line of spectators an stand glowering at him.  The prisoners have moved back, w watching for the next move.

You wouldn't listen, would you? Almost wearily, he goes to the fence.  This isn't somethi he likes, but his authority is at stake here, and he has choice.  As the CAMERA PANS him to the fence we see that  some non-Aryan adults have drifted over to see what the  disturbance is.
(to the children)
Go on.  Get back. The children don't move.  Their eyes are on Helmut.  The  guard shouts over to the adults standing behind the child
You back there, get them out of here. The adults begin to gather up the children.

They had nothing to do with it.  It  was all my doing. The guard turns and comes up to face Helmut.  He studies for a moment, then hits him a vicious backhand slap acros the face.  Taken by surprise, Helmut staggers backward an falls.  A murmur runs through the prisoners.  The childre still near the fence, cry out with alarm.  Seeing their  terror, Helmut is determined to make it look like just an act.  With a painful effort he gets to his feet, smiles a the children, turns and salutes the guard, knocking himse down again.  A couple of children giggle.  The FIRST SS  OFFICER quickly steps forward to stand behind the guard. He holds a swagger stick in his right hand, which he  repeatedly whacks into the palm of his left hand.  He loo down at Helmut.

Get up. Helmut struggles to his feet.  He glances over at the  children.  They are all watching him.  He takes a deep br winks at the little ones, then salaams before the SS Offi and the guard.  Some of the children giggle.  This infuri the SS officer.  He raises the swagger stick and brings i down hard on Helmut's head knocking him to his knees.  Th children scream with terror.  The SS Officer raises the s to hit Helmut again, but Keltner, in an almost instinctiv reaction, catches hold of his arm.
The children! Not in front of the  children!

The SS Officer turns and brings the stick down on Keltner He hits him over and over, each blow more vicious. MED. SHOT - HELMUT - FRIGHTENED CHILDREN IN B.G. Helmut turns away from the beating, pulls his jacket up o his head and starts to walk around like a headless man  stumbling and falling over his own feet.  The children, m still screaming, turn their eyes away from the SS Officer watch Helmut's antics.

head_text.subj: FRANZ, GALT, UHLMANN, LUDWIG, ADOLF, HERMAN A

text: The horror-stricken men stand frozen as the SS Officer  continues to hit Keltner until he drops to the ground.   Suddenly Franz breaks away from the men and charges at th First SS Officer.
Franz runs INTO CAMERA and attempts to stop the First SS  Officer.  The Second SS Officer whips his pistol out, aim carefully and FIRES a shot into Franz's head.

Uhlmann stands speechless and dumbfounded.  Galt cowers. Beads of perspiration pour from his brow.  Adolf weeps bi tears as Herman places his arm around his shoulder to com him, and himself as well.  Ludwig, dead to any emotion, s turns and walks away into the crowd.

Helmut is now, more than ever, the clown, as he goes into frenzied version of the "Clap Dance".  The complete  incongruity of his behavior leaves the spectators stunned WIDER ANGLE - SHOWING THE CHILDREN IN B.G. The children are no longer screaming, instead they are  watching Helmut as though they are hypnotized.

head_text.subj: HELMUT, GUARD, SS MEN, OTHER GUARDS

text: The guard, fully aware that the sadist SS men may take ac against Helmut, quickly motions for two of the other guar to take Helmut away.  The First SS Officer, still panting with exhaustion, shows his approval of the action taken b the guard.  The two guards seize Helmut by the arms and b dragging him off toward the administration building.  The prisoners move away before the guards holding Helmut, for a sort of line of march for them.  As they drag Helmut al he waves back at the children, makes a funny face and mov his feet in something approaching a dance step.

SHOOTING FROM THE BACK of the cell toward the door.  The  cell is about eight feet long and four feet wide with a s door at the far end.  The cell is bare.  We HEAR men  approaching, and a guard opens the door letting in a shaf of bright light.  Two guards hoist the unconcious Helmut  into the cell and drop him onto the floor.
He lies in a heap on the floor, his face swollen from a s beating.
The guards walk out, slamming the door shut leaving the c pitch dark.
Window shade quickly rolls up letting in a steam of blind sunlight.
Lt. Scharff is by the window, having just rolled up the w shade.  Colonel Bestler is on the phone and obviously  exasperated by what he is hearing.
(on phone)
Yes. (pause)
Yes.  Yes, I understand perfectly.   However, I don't see how we can be  held responsible. (pause)
Our orders were very clear.  We were  to have the freight car ready to be  picked up at midnight. (pause)
Of course, I'm aware the operation  must be kept secret. (pause)
I just don't have the staff to send  down there now and... Yes, I'll wait. He puts hand over mouthpiece to talk to Scharff.
The freight car wasn't picked up.
It's still down there on the siding!
Some stupid mix up.  If they think... The SOUND of the voice coming over the phone causes him t literally snap to attention.
Yes, General. (pause)
Yes, I'm as distressed about the  situation as you are. (long pause during  which he nods his  head)
Yes.  Personally!  Immediately!   Yes, General.  You can leave it in  my hands. (pause)
Heil Hitler! He puts down the instrument and turns at once to Scharff.
Who did you leave in charge down  there?
Sergeant Hoffman.  Very reliable.
Apparently not reliable enough.  The  cargo seems to be raising quite a  fuss.
(explanatory)
Fifty children, sir!  In a boxcar!
I know.  I know.  But the siding  isn't far from town.  The General  doesn't want unauthorized persons  getting curious.  Understand?
I'll get some men down there right  away.
Men!  You'll get yourself down there. And take at least a dozen guards  with you.  Don't let anyone get close  to that boxcar...  under any  circumstances.  No one !
Yes, sir. Scharff turns to leave the office, but after a few steps stops and turns back toward Bestler, a look of concern on his face.
Sir? Bestler looks up.
I wondered, sir, if you might have  any suggestions as... well...  how  do we quiet children?
Use any method you can, but shut  them up.  That's an order. Scharff is disappointed at not getting some help from Bes Suddenly his face brightens.
Sir, the clown! Bestler looks at him quizzically.
The one who amused the children
Out of the question.  The man's being  disciplined for that very thing.  We  can't change our position now.
No one need know.
He'd know. Scharff thinks this over.  Suddenly his face brightens.
Sir, if I could guarantee he'd never  say anything. Bestler looks interested.
You see, sir, he's been trying to  get a review of his case.  Claims  he's here by mistake.  I could tell  him you would recommend the review.
A man who wants something.  Good.   Very good strategy, Lieutenant. (he turns to face  Scharff)
However, when you bring him back  here, return him to solitary and  keep him there. (a beat)
I've seen the best of men, after  several years in solitary, unable to  remember even their own names.
Then I have your permission to take  the clown.
Permission granted.
A small open truck with 12 soldiers in the back, followed a staff car, move along the road.
DRIVER is in the front seat, Helmut and Scharff in the ba

Helmut has been cleaned up, but still shows the effects o the beating and his stay in solitary.  Holding a small mi he is applying his makeup.  He occasionally closes or tri to shade his eyes from the light.  They ride on in silenc Scharff stares straight ahead.
Wish you could've gotten the big  shoes.  The children laugh so when  they see them flopping up and down. Scharff makes no reply.  Helmut starts to put on his big  black mouth.
(a touch of the old  arrogance)
The Commandant, himself, asked for  me! (a beat)
You say he's personally requesting a  review of my case!  Why, that means  I'm practically on my way back to  Berlin. (studies mouth in  mirror)
Should be red.  Mouth looks better  in red. (a beat)
Know the first thing I'm going to do  when I get to Berlin?  Buy an overcoat  with a fur collar.  Had such a coat.   Very elegant. Very elegant. (finishing the up- turned corners of  mouth)
It's a good idea... moving the  children. Scharff reacts to this.  He looks sharply at Helmut.
Prison's no place for children. I  said all along that it was some kind  of mistake.
(uncomfortable)
Finish your makeup.  We're almost  there.
Know what Johann Keltner said?
Who?

Keltner.  From my barracks.  The  minister. He said... Let me think. He said... men who wage war on  children. That's it. Men who wage  war on children... commit such a  crime... (a beat as he thinks)

... such a heinous crime.  That's  it.  Men who wage war on children  commit such a heinous crime that  even the devil damns their souls. Scharff looks as though he'd just been slapped across the face.  He quickly turns toward the window.  Helmut inspec his reflection in the mirror as he draws black vertical l down over each eye -- giving him a very lost, sad, deject look.

as the truck and staff car leave the highway and jolt dow short roadway to a railroad siding where a boxcar sits on the tracks.  Uniformed GUARDS stand watch on both sides o the car, which has the door nearest the CAMERA, partially open.  The truck and staff car pull up to the nearest box The soldiers jump from the rear of the truck, one of them carrying a large burlap sack.
as Scharff gets out of the car, from the boxcar comes the SOUND of children crying.
(to Helmut in car)
Wait here. Scharff strides purposefully over to Sergeant Hoffman, th guard beside the open door.  Hoffman salutes Scharff.
Any word about the train yet?
No, sir.  The last we heard -- it  won't get here until evening.
Anyone been around?
No, sir.
With all that wailing, it's a wonder.   Couldn't you keep them quiet?
I didn't know what to do, Lieutenant.   I was afraid to close both doors.
(to other soldiers)
Keep a tight guard on the whole area.   No one gets near here.  Understand? (to Hoffman)
You post them.
(saluting)
Yes, sir. Hoffman moves over to soldiers and begins giving them the orders.
(to soldier holding  the sack)
Leave that here. The soldier puts down the sack, and hurries off after the others with Hoffman leading the way.  Scharff turns towar the staff car.
(calling to Helmut)
Over here, Clown. Helmut quickly gets out of the car and moves over to Scha He looks toward the partially open door.
They're crying.
(indicating the sack)
Take that in to them. Helmut picks up the sack and peers into it.
What is it?
Bread.  They won't wait so loud with  their mouths full.
(shocked)
How... how long have they been here?
You just get in there and keep them  quiet.  You can do that, can't you? Helmut nods.  Scharff puts his hand on Helmut's shoulder. Helmut stiffens under his touch.
Do a good job and I'll personally  ask that you get a favorable decision  on your case.  Understand?

Yes, sir. Helmut moves over to the half open door of the boxcar, th CAMERA MOVING with him.  Just before he looks inside, he  puts a wide grin on his face.  But when he does peer into the car, his eyes cease to smile.

In one end of the car the children are huddled together i one frightened, wailing mass.  They do not even notice He at first, so great is their sorrow.  The little ones clin to the larger youngsters, who, in turn, cling together. small ones weep hysterically , as children do when they h been crying for a very long time.  The CAMERA PULLS BACK that Helmut is in f.g.   He slides the boxcar door open f throwing more light on the children.  This brings renewed walls of anguish from the youngsters, who cluster togethe more fiercely.  But one little boy sneaks a look at the d expecting to see more guards.  When he sees Helmut, his t filled eyes widen.  He can scarcely believe what he sees, much less verbalize it.  He tugs frantically at an OLDER  GIRL he has been clutching.  She looks first at him, then Helmut.  She, too, can hardly believe it.
(tentatively)
Doork? (shrill with  recognition)
It's Doork.  It is!  It is! The children begin untangling quickly.  Faces appear betw legs, around skirts and over shoulders.  For a moment the can only stare at Helmut, speechless with wonder.
(gently)

So this is where you've been hiding? That breaks the silence, and the children begin squealing libbed expressions of greeting and relief.  They repeat h name time and again:  "Doork, Doork, Doork."  As one... t youngsters surge toward him.  The little boy who first sa him reaches him first.  He drops to his knees and puts hi arms around Helmut's neck, hugging him furiously.  Helmut returns the embrace.
I want to go home.  Take me home.
Now, now, there's nothing to cry  about.  We're going to have fun. (disengaging himself  and picking up the  sack)
Here.  I brought you something. (he tosses it into  the car)
The children pounce on the sack and  tug at it, unsure what it is except  that it's a gift from Helmut.

Wait now.  Don't open it yet.  Wait'll  I get in.  You help me. He backs up a few steps, the CAMERA PULLING BACK with him Then he runs toward the car and, with strength he really  doesn't have, jumps up so that he gets his arms on the fl of the boxcar.  He heaves himself forward partially into and the children grab his clothes to help him inside.  A  couple of the older boys seize the seat of his pants and  finally pull him in.
FAVORING Helmut as he rolls over and jumps up, waggling h head from side to side in the manner of a Jack-in-the-box The children watch him big-eyed.  A few giggle.
Look, I'm a Jack-in-the-box. He gestures around to indicate that he is, indeed, in a b

We're all Jacks-in-the-box -- the  same box. The children laugh, and some begin imitating Helmut's hea movements.  Others do the same, and still others, includi the Czech youngsters, until all are waggling their heads each other and loving it.  Then, out of sheer adoration, youngest of the children close in on Helmut and hug him a his legs.  Slowly he stops waggling his head and stretche out his arms to embrace as many of them as he can -- almo as if trying to protect them.  Suddenly the gaiety dissol and the children go solemnly silent.  Helmut reacts.
Well... who's hungry. Almost in unison, the children shout "I am", again forget their unhappiness.
All right, I want everybody to sit  down.  When I count three, everybody  sit.  Ready?   One, two... On the count of two, many of the youngsters sit down.  He feigns surprise.

Oh, you're too fast.  Three! This brings a burst of giggles, and the remaining childre sit down... the Czechs following the example of the other Helmut opens the burlap sack and begins handing out piece of black bread.  The children grab at the chunks and gnaw voraciously.  When all of the youngsters have been given bread, Helmut takes a piece and bites into it with great  relish.  After a few chews on the bread:
Now... what'll we do? There is a long moment of silence, then the little blonde girl with the rag doll speaks up timidly.
I want to see my Mommy. Helmut is brought up short.  For a beat he searches his b frantically for an answer.  Then he goes to the child and kneels beside her.
You would?  All right.
You know where she is?
She's right here with you.
I don't see her.
That's because you don't know how to  look.  I'll show you.  Close your  eyes. (to the other children)

All of you... close your eyes. The little girl closes her eyes and one by one the other  youngsters do also.  The Czech children look at each othe then at the other children, then they too close their eye
Everybody's eyes shut?  Now, think  about your mommys and Daddys... There,  don't you see them?  Can't you see  their faces? The children, marvelling at this feat, ad lib expressions assent.
So you see!  They're right here with  you.  All you have to do is look in  your hearts.
(putting her hand  over her heart)
Does Mommy see me, Doork?
(deeply touched)
Yes, she does.  She has you safe in  her heart, too. The silence in the car tells Helmut that sadness has retu to the children.  He brightens quickly and rises.
I've got an idea.  You all know my  name, but I don't know yours.  So  let's find out everybody's name,  shall we? He points to a boy of about ten in the group.
You... come here and I'll show you  what we'll do. The boy, honored at being singled out, rises and comes to Helmut, who takes a stubby pencil from his pocket.
What's your name?
(timidly)
Willie.
Willie.  That's a good name.  How do  you spell it?
Fine.  I'll just write that on top  of your head. Using the eraser end of the pencil, Helmut carefully trac the letters on top of the boy's head.  The youngster peer upward, wondering.
There.  See, this way we'll all be  able to tell everybody else's name  just by looking at his head.
still looking up, but now doubtful.
Did you really?
Of course I did.  Here... He pulls an older boy to his feet, winks at him and point to the first boy's head.
(to the older boy)
Tell him what it says.
(giggling)
It says Willie.
(impressed)
Really?  Truly? He puts his hand to his head.
Be careful.  Don't smear it. (he glances around)

Let's see now... Yes.  You shall be  next. He points to a Czech girl of about six.  He motions for h to come over to him.  She shyly bows her head.  Her frien push her forward. Helmut holds out his hand to her, she g it.
What is your name? She looks at him, then at the other Czech children.  They all giggle.
(squatting down beside  her)
Forgive me.  I don't speak your  language. He gently plants a kiss on her cheek and she puts an arm  around his neck.
(to others)
See!  We understand each other.   Now... (he points to Willie)
Willie. (he points to himself)
Doork. (points again to Willie)
Willie. (pointing to himself)
Doork. The child's eyes light up and she whispers into Helmut's  ear.
A beautiful name!  Now you tell all  the children.
(almost a whisper)
Inga.
It's such a pretty name... say it  again.
(more sure of herself)
Inga! She quickly bows her head for Helmut to outline her name the top of it.
(with a flourish of  his pencil)
I-N-G-A.  There it is. The little girl gives a quick curtsy and hurries back to group.  Helmut glances around at the children.
Let's see now.  Who wants to be next. The little girl with the doll presses forward.
You? Shaking her head she holds up the doll.
Her?
So the little children will know her  name.
Of course.  That way she can't get  lost, can she?  What's her name?
Frederika.
(mock dismay)
Frederika? He studies the top of doll's tiny head.  Then he holds up his hand and measures off a distance of about three inche in the air with thumb and forefinger.
Frederika! Next he puts the doll's head between his thumb and forefi illustrating that the head is too small for the name.
Couldn't we just make it Freda?
(solemnly)
Oh, no!  Frederika. Helmut shrugs, closes one eye and begins writing in tiny  letters on the doll's head.  The children laugh delighted

Sergeant Hoffmann is walking his post beside the open doo of the boxcar.  Inside we can see Helmut and the children and HEAR their laughter. The CAMERA PANS over to the staff car, where Scharff sits the front seat smoking a cigarette and waiting.
It is perhaps two hours later.   Sergeant Hoffman is now  leaning wearily against the boxcar near the door.  The CA PANS over to the staff car, where Scharff is dozing in th back seat.

From within the boxcar we can HEAR Helmut SINGING softly the children.  Sergeant Hoffman is listening.  Finally he takes something from his pocket, goes to the door of the  boxcar and sticks his head inside.
The children are scattered about, either sleeping or near sleep, many of them cuddled close to Helmut, who sits nea the door with his back against the side of the car, croon
(whispering)
Clown.  Clown, can you play one of  these? He holds out a harmonica.  Helmut leans over to get it, b careful not to disturb the children.
I got it to send home to my boy...   but if it'll help...
It will.  It will. (he takes it)
You won't say anything to the  Lieutenant.
I promise. He leans back and looks at the harmonica, then he has a s thought as Hoffman's head disappears.  He leans back towa the door.
Guard... guard. Hoffman reappears at door.
It's going to be dark soon.  The  little ones may be afraid.  Do you  think... well... could you get some  kind of a light for in here?
(angry)
Want to get me in trouble? Helmut nods that he understands Hoffman's situation.
(trying to justify  himself)
I would if I could.

I know.  I know you would. Again Hoffman's face disappears.  Helmut leans back and b experimenting with the harmonica.  Actually he can play i only slightly, but he manages to get some sort of soft tu out of it.  The CAMERA PULLS BACK SLOWLY to include the  children, most of who are resting peacefully, secure in  Helmut's presence.  But suddenly a little dark haired, da eyed girl of about six, sits upright and cries out, frigh by a bad dream.  Helmut reacts.  The child looks around t boxcar as if she can't remember how she got there and beg crying inconsolably.  Some of the other children stir.  H quickly but carefully disengages himself from the tots ar him and picks his way over to the girl.  He kneels beside her, and the CAMERA MOVES UP to --
The child continues crying, but more softly, he wide wet  eyes on Helmut.
(gently)
What's the matter? (she only stares at  him)

It's all right -- just a bad dream. He tries to put a comforting arm around her, but she shri away continuing to sob softly.  Realizing that words won' help, he turns to the harmonica for communication, serena her with a soft but sprightly tune of his own improvisati It is hardly a masterpiece, but it has the desired effect The girl stops sobbing, and when Helmut finishes the tune makes a real funny face and she timorously puts a hand up touch his make-up, but pulls it back quickly.  With an  affectionate smile, Helmut takes her hand and runs it ove his face, pretending that her touch tickles him.  As he  laughs, the child begins to smile faintly.  He shows her traces of chalk make-up on her fingers, and she giggles. His conquest is all but complete.  He picks the youngster up, and holding her like a dancing partner, pretends to d with her to a little tune he hums.  She loves this and la outright.  When Helmut finally puts her down, he kisses h on the cheek and turns his cheek in an unspoken request f a return kiss.  The girl shyly and quickly gives Helmut's cheek a peck.  Grinning, Helmut pats the spot where she k him to show his appreciation for her wonderful gift.
The older girl we saw earlier calls to him in a hushed vo
Doork. Helmut moves over and squats down beside her and the CAME MOVES IN to --
Where are they sending us?
(shaking his head)
Don't know.
Do you have children? Helmut looks around at the children.  He smiles sadly.
I do now.
Scharff, dozing in the back seat, is awakened by the SOUN of an approaching train o.s.  He listens, glances at his  watch, shakes his head and gets out of the car.
As Scharff strides to the boxcar, where Sergeant Hoffman also hear the locomotive.  He salutes as Scharff comes up the CAMERA FOLLOWING him.
It finally got here.
Yes, sir.

Help them get the car coupled on. We want to move it out of here as fast as possible.  Be s the doors are locked.  And, get the clown off. Hoffman salutes, and Scharff moves off toward the approac locomotive and freight cars being backed up to the boxcar
It is backing down the siding toward the boxcar.
With a cautious look around, he reaches under the waiting boxcar and brings out a box-type, battery operated lanter He goes to the boxcar door and peers inside.
(calling)
All right, clown, time to get off. Helmut appears at the door and looks down.
What is it?
Train is here.  They are hooking it  up now. (he hoists the lantern  inside)
Here.  Tell them not to light it up  until the doors are closed. Helmut gives him a look of deep gratitude.
(curtly)
And get off right now. Just then the boxcar is jolted as the locomotive makes co and Hoffman runs off toward the front of the car.
The jolt has awakened several of the children, who gather around Helmut in the dimness of the car, frightened and  bewildered.
We're moving.  What's happening?   What was the noise?  Doork, where  are we going?
(forced gaiety)
It's nothing.  You're going for a  train ride.  What do you think of  that?  A real train ride.
(pressing close --  sensing his anxiety)
Is it far?  Are you coming, too?  I  don't want a train ride.
Oh, it'll be fun.  I would like to  come, but I don't think I can.
(pleading)
Please come, Doork.  Please.  Please.   Please.
I can't.  They want me to stay here. There are cries from the children, whose pleading eyes ma Helmut terribly uncomfortable.  He backs toward the door.

But... I'll come to see you.  Soon  as I can. And, I want you all to  promise me to be very good.  No  crying. The children stare at him silently, their eyes unconsciou accusing.  With him goes all their security.  Helmut know it, but he has no choice.  When he reaches the door...
If you want me...  remember, just  close your eyes.

head_text.subj: LITTLE GIRL WITH THE DARK EYES

text: Wordlessly, she shuts her eyes -- tight.
Following the dark-eyed girl's example, the smaller child one by one, close their eyes.
Near tears with emotion, he wavers.  Then with great cont
(huskily)
Goodbye.

He turns and sits down on the floor of the car with his f hanging outside.  He is just about to jump down when he i stopped by a LOUD WAIL of anguish from one of the childre behind him.  He turns and looks back at them.

A BOY of about six, one of the Czech youngsters, is cryin with the dejection of a lad who has just lost everything. The other little Czechs and the older girl who first  recognized Helmut at the boxcar door are trying unsuccess to console him.  Between cooing and patting the boy's  shoulder, the girl throws accusing looks at Helmut.
Uncertain what to do, Helmut glances around outside.   Satisfied that the train isn't going to move at once, he  gets up and goes to the children.
What's this now?  Crying?  After all  the fun we've had? The boy only looks at Helmut and goes right on crying.  H looks helplessly at the older girl.
It's his birthday.  He thought there  would be presents.
(to girl)
He's a Czech.   Do you speak...
(annoyed)
Of course not! Helmut is angry with the girl because he really wants to off the train and yet can't because of the accusing look her eyes.
(pointedly)
Then how do you know it's his...  birthday?
(with typical child  logic)
He told me.
He speaks German?
No.
But he told you it's his birthday? The girl nods firmly as do the other children.  The boy  watches it all, wide-eyed.  Helmut figures to put an end this.
What date is this?
(after thinking it  over)
Why, it's his birthday! This is too much for Helmut to fathom.  He turns his head away, trying to think.

Don't you believe him? Helmut turns back to them, looking first at the girl, the at the boy, his little upturned tear-stained face full of wonder.  Helmut softens, recalling perhaps his own birthd disappointment.
Of course, I do. (pats boy's head)
Tell him I wish him a happy birthday.
He knows that.  But... but what're  you going to do about a present? Helmut fans his clothes, finds the harmonica and produces with a flourish.
Aha, the very thing.  He can be the  clown while I'm gone.
As Helmut bows and holds out the harmonica to him.

Happy birthday. The boy looks solemnly at Helmut and the harmonica.  He  doesn't quite seem to understand what this is all about, the harmonica is enticing.  He looks up at his countrymen for encouragement.  They smile at him, and he takes the  harmonica, examines it, then blows into it experimentally When he hears the SOUND that comes out, he brightens.  Th the little girl with the rag doll comes forward and offer it to the boy.  He looks at her strangely, one of the old German boys scoffs.
He's a boy!  Dolls are for girls. The little girl is hurt, and looks to Helmut for support.

When you give something you love...   it doesn't matter if it's the right  thing. He takes the doll and puts one of it's hands in the boy's hand, the other in the little girl's.  They stand looking each other and sharing the doll.  Helmut looks towards th door apprehensively, but there seems to be no action outs and there are the eyes of the children on him.
Maybe we have time for a birthday  game.  A quick one.  Let me take a  look.
Helmut goes back to the door.  He glances around outside. There still seems to be time.  He returns to the children
Everybody line up behind me now, and  I'll show you how a train goes.   Wait -- the harmonica. Helmut looks around for the new owner of the harmonica. goes over to him.
May I borrow it back... for just a  minute or two? The boy studies him dubiously with that "Indian-giver" lo in his eyes.
For just a minute -- then I'll give  it right back to you. (trying a sort of  sign language)
Just for the game. Finally the boy hands over the harmonica and manages a sm because he sees all the other children smiling at him.
Good.  Now everybody...  line up  behind me. The children scramble into line behind him.  Helmut looks back at them.
Grab hold of the one in front of  you...  'cause we're going to be a  fast express train. The children, laughing and giggling, grab hold of one ano
(calling out)

All aboard.  All aboard. He puts the harmonica to his lips and begins huffing and  puffing on it, imitating a train.  He begins to shuffle h feet and move slowly down the side of the car... the chil holding on for dear life and following him... their eyes  shining with expectation as Helmut begins to quicken his  pace.

Dim shafts of light from the two small square vent openin near the top on each side, gives the boxcar an eerie look Helmut stops abruptly as he hears the slamming of the doo The children pile up behind him.
He moves quickly to the door and tugs at it.  Finding it  locked, he pounds on it.
Open the door!  Let me out...  LET

But the train NOISES drown his voice.  Then the boxcar  suddenly lurches and starts to move forward.  Helmut's  pounding weakens and stops.  He turns from the door, his  face reflecting his fright.  The children, not quite  understanding what has happened, gather around him, and p on him.  He manages to control his fear, and looking at t children, he manages a big smile.
Guess I'm going with you after all. He switches on the lantern and holds it high so its rays  cover all the children.
Let's play some more, Doork? Helmut glances down at the tot, started by the suggestion Then he nods in a stunned sort of way.  He puts the harmo to his mouth and begins puffing on it.
Scharff and Sergeant Hoffman stand watching the boxcar mo away.
I'm glad that's over.  Call in the  sentries.
Yes, sir. He starts to move away.
Kessler in the car?
Kessler?
The clown?
(looking around)
I... I guess he is, sir.

You GUESS! Scharff races to the car with Sergeant Hoffman right behi him. The CAMERA FOLLOWS them. Scharff peers inside and finds the car empty.  With an an glance at Hoffman, he hurries to the truck and looks in t cab.  It too is empty.
(moving back toward  Hoffman)
I told you to get him off the train.
I told him, sir.  HE was standing  right by the door.  I'm sure he got  off.
Did you see him?
Why, I...
DID you?
You told me to see that the car was  coupled on.  When I came back...   Why wouldn't he get off?
Idiot! (shouting)
Guards.  GUARDS! The other soldiers come running from o.s.
The clown prisoner is missing.  He  may have escaped.  Search the area.   If he got off the train he must be  around here someplace. The soldiers rush o.s. into the deepening darkness.
You know what happens if he gets  away.
(hopefully)
He can't get very far. Scharff looks o.s. after the disappearing train.
If he's on that train -- he's going  farther than you know ---
The rear of the boxcar is just disappearing from sight in the darkness.
... or he knows.

It is the next morning.  Light is coming from the vents a the lantern which hangs from a peg in the middle of the r side of the car.  Helmut is asleep on the floor with the  children huddled around him.  He lies on his side with on arm thrown protectively over the little Czech girl, Inga, and Willie.  Behind him, the Czech birthday boy and the g with the doll are cuddled close to him.  Other youngsters have their heads on his legs and feet, and all are as clo to him as they can get. He is, in fact, a sort of human bed.  From the train NOIS o.s. we can tell that the freight train is slowing down. Then, with a jolt, it stops, and o.s. we HEAR a truck eng approaching.  Helmut stirs and sits up, trying to get his bearings.  This arouses some of the children and they too sit up and look around.
What is it?  Are we there, Doork? Where are we?  Why are we stopping?

I don't know. He untangles himself, rises and stretches his numbed arms and legs.  He starts toward the door, but it slides open  suddenly and a BURLY GUARD vaults inside.   Behind him we see a truck similar to a moving van being backed up to th boxcar.  Helmut blinks uncertainly at the light pouring  through the door.
Everybody up.  No noise. The children are too startled to move.  The guard notices Helmut and reacts.
Who the hell are you?
Where are we?
How the devil did you get in here?
I... I'm from the other prison.  Got  locked in -- by accident.
Ah, for... (shouting out the  door)
Sergeant!

We see now that the train has stopped at an isolated sidi The truck has backed up almost to the door of the boxcar. SERGEANT climbs down from the cab of the van and hurries the boxcar door, the CAMERA PANNING him there.
What's the matter?
Look at this.  He's from the other  camp.  Got in here with the shipment.
How did that happen?
I... I was taking care of the children  back there and... accidentally got  locked in.
Of all the... What's your name?
(realizing he's in  big trouble)
Doork.  Helmut Doork. The Sergeant fumes for a moment, then...
(to the guard)
Put him in the truck with the others.   And, let's get going.
ANGLE to the door as the Sergeant disappears.  Reaching o the Burly Guard lowers the tailgate of the truck so that forms a bridge to the boxcar.
(to the children)

All right, in the truck, quick now! The children, most of whom are on their feet now, hesitat looking to Helmut for guidance.  The guard seizes one  youngster and shoves him toward the door.  Instead, howev the child flies to Helmut and grabs him around the legs.
I said move!
(quickly)
Wait.  Let me. (to the children)
Everybody up.  Come on.  Up, up, up. He moves around, helping the still seated children to the feet.  When they're all up...
(to Helmut)
Not you.
Don't you want me to stay with them?   They'll be frightened without me.
Not for long, they won't.
(to guard)
That's enough.  Get them inside and  keep them quiet. Burly guard starts to prod the children but they don't mo their eyes are fixed on Helmut.
(threateningly)
Do as he says.  And, don't worry,  I'll be with you soon.  I promise. Reluctantly, the children march off.  They look back  frequently at Helmut who waves to them.
(to Helmut)
Come along, now. They walk over to a two-story building.  Helmut looks bac in the direction of the children, then looks about the ca
This is just another prison.
What'd you expect?
I thought the children were going to  a better place. The Sergeant, with an incredulous look on his face, stare at Helmut.

The cell is a small, bare cubicle containing only a cot a an open toilet.  In the wall, fronting on the prison yard there is a small barred window.  Helmut stops pacing and  moves over to it, and looks out.  The CAMERA SWINGS so th it is SHOOTING PAST Helmut's head through the window.  At the far end of the yard we can see the windowless stone  buildings.  As Helmut stares out at them, we HEAR approac footsteps. Helmut stiffens, turns toward the door as the  SOUND of the footsteps grows louder and louder. The CAMERA SWINGS toward the door as it opens to reveal  CAPTAIN CURT RUNKEL, a slender, impeccably groomed and  thoroughly Nazified officer of the elite S.S.  He is the  embodiment of all Hitlerian ideals.  Runkel strides into cell.
(over shoulder to  guard at door)

Close the door, and wait out there. Guard closes the door.  Runkel studies Helmut coldly.  Wi taking his eyes off Helmut, he pulls out a cigarette case takes out cigarette, lights it and slowly inhales.
You're a remarkable man.  Very  remarkable. Helmut stirs uneasily.
Have you any idea where you are? Helmut shakes his head.
Auschwitz.  This is Auschwitz. (a beat)
Mean anything to you? (before Helmut can  answer)
You may have observed we're enlarging  our facilities. He moves over to the window and looks out, puffing slowly his cigarette.
Still a great deal of work to be  done. (proudly)
It's going to be our most efficient,  most modern prison. (he turns and smiles)
And, I might add, most unique. (walks back towards  Helmut, studying him  carefully)
Yes, you are a remarkable man.  I  always wonder about remarkable men. (then evenly)
Why did you come here?
I explained.  I got locked in the  boxcar and...
(cuts in - still bland)
Ah, yes.  An accident.  Unavoidable  I suppose.
I was taking care -- I mean, the  Commandant requested me to take care  of the children.
(a slight note of  mockery)
The Commandant! Runkel tosses his cigarette on the floor and very deliber grinds it out with his boot.
I've spoken to YOUR Commandant.  He  hs you listed as an escaped prisoner.
Escaped!  But...
(finishing it for him)
... it was an accident. (his face close to  Helmut's)
Are you one of them, clown?
(terrorized at the  thought of death)
No... no!  I'm not one of them.  I'm  not ! Runkel smiles, moves away from Helmut.
You misunderstand completely.  The  Judas goat is never killed.  He isn't  worth killing. (moves to cell door)
I'm just asking you to lead them.
His eyes plead, "No.  I can't do it.  No."
Not... even to save your own life? For a brief moment, Helmut struggles to find the courage stand up to Runkel -- but he has no courage and he sinks  slowly to his knees, his head bowed.
(victorious)
I'm glad to see you're not a self- appointed martyr.
Runkel towers above Helmut who sits back on his haunches, leaning against the wall.

Just think!  Now you're really one  of us. The truth of Runkel's remark hits Helmut like a devastati blow.   He turns his face to the wall in shame.  Runkel w to the door, raps on it, the guard outside swings it open
(attempting to get to  his feet)
Sir... Sir... could I... could I  have a little time with them before  ... before... His voice trails off.  Runkel looks at Helmut while he th it over.  He moves back to the middle of the cell.
Yes.  Yes, of course. (he looks at his watch)
I can give you about half an hour. (a little smile lights  his face)
You see, we're not heartless men  here.
ANGLE to the door as Helmut and the Sergeant approach fro o.s.  Helmut has freshened his make-up.
Remember what I told you.
There won't be any trouble. Helmut goes to the door and starts to open it.  The CAMER MOVES UP to --
With a great effort, he composes himself and throws open door.

ANGLE to the door, where Helmut stands wearing an enormou grin.  The children are about the barren room in little  groups.  When they see Helmut, they leap up and run to hi clinging to him as he closes the door behind him and move into the room.

Doork, Doork, you came back.  You  came back.  We thought you'd left  us.  Don't leave us, Doork. The children continue to ad lib expressions of mingled fe and delight at his return.  Helmut goes among them, patti their heads comfortingly.
There.  There.  It's all right. It's  all right.   Everything is going to  be all right. When the youngsters are calmed, Helmut holds up his hands for silence.

Now I want everyone to put on a big  smile and sit down, because we're  going to have more fun than we've  ever had. Slowly, still unconvinced that they have nothing to fear, the children sit on the floor.
Good.  We'll start by seeing that we  all have our names on our heads. The children begin to lower their heads so Helmut can che to see if their names are still there.
(as he moves among  them)
Yes, yes.  There's Fritz, Maria,  Sadie, Inga, Josef, Nathan, Helga,  Willie... The little girl with the rag doll holds up the doll for H to see.

Ah, yes, Frederika!  Good.  I see  all of your names. This is almost too much for Helmut, but he manages to con himself by turning away for a beat.  Then he turns back t the children, his big smile back in place.
Now... on with the show.  Just watch  this.
Their little faces are troubled, worried.
It is a half hour later, and now the children are laughin at something Helmut is doing o.s.  The CAMERA PULLS BACK

Helmut is walking an imaginary tightrope.  Every few step he almost loses his balance, but with comical gyrations h manages to complete the walk.  He bows deeply to the chil and falls flat on his face.  The youngsters laugh, applau and squeal delightedly.
Helmut is lying on the floor near the boy.  He looks up a the tot and grins.

Doork!  Doork... you're great ! Helmut grabs Willie and holds him close while he fights b his tears.   Willie plants a big kiss on his cheek.  Helm scrambles to his feet, the CAMERA PULLING BACK to --
SHOOTING PAST Helmut to the door as it opens, revealing t Sergeant, his face expressionless.  Helmut reacts.
(to Helmut)
It's time.
Just a few more minutes? The sergeant shakes his head.
I'll bring them. The children are watching him, puzzled.
What's the matter, Doork?  Where are  we going?  You come with us this  time.  Where're they taking us.
(trying to think what  to say)
They... they want us to move to  another building... where we'll have  more room... to play. (a beat)
Tell you what.  Let's make it a big  circus parade.  Everybody get in a  line behind... He picks up Willie and stands him near the door.
(continuing)
... behind Willie here. The children scramble up and begin forming a line behind very proud Willie.  Helmut looks around for the boy with harmonica.

Now, where's our band?  The harmonica? He sees the boy and goes to him.  Helmut pantomimes playi the harmonica and points to himself.  The boy smiles wide fishes the harmonica out of his pocket and holds it up.

There we are?  Everybody ready?   Here we go. Helmut takes his place at the head of the line, like the  Pied Piper, leads the youngsters out the door, playing a  crude sort of circus parade music.  The little children g excitedly as they troupe out.  The older ones seem less  certain, but as long as Helmut is with them, they feel se

As the procession of youngsters emerges from the barracks with Helmut dancing along at its head.  The Sergeant and other two Guards stand watching in disbelief as the line  turns and moves along toward the first of the windowless  buildings.
They look at each other incredulously.  What they are see surpasses their imagination.

SHOOTING from a HIGH ANGLE as the procession moves toward the CAMERA.  Helmut looks back at his charges from time t time, smiling and waving and always puffing away on the  harmonica.  The children smile back, some timidly and som bit fearfully, but all smile.

CAMERA PANS in on the children as they march behind Helmu We see some of them strutting, their little arms swinging freely.  Some of the little ones have to skip to keep up  with the others.  They are all smiling.
